content.raw: So the convert_to_plot function accepts positions in the code units of the original data set. The code units of the halos dataset are not guaranteed to (and in fact are typically not) be the same as the code units of the original dataset. So this bit takes the halo_data positions, puts them in Mpc, then divides by the length_unit (Mpc/code_length as I understood it) so that px and py are in code units of the plot.data.
content.html: So the convert_to_plot function accepts positions in the code units of the original data set. The code units of the halos dataset are not guaranteed to (and in fact are typically not) be the same as the code units of the original dataset. So this bit takes the halo_data positions, puts them in Mpc, then divides by the length_unit (Mpc/code_length as I understood it) so that px and py are in code units of the plot.data.

content.raw: That's fascinating, and I totally didn't think of it.  I think this *might* lead to wrong behavior in some cases, but I don't immediately have a solution.  What about converting to Mpccm, then using `pf.arr` to create new unit registries or something?  Hmm.
content.html: That's fascinating, and I totally didn't think of it. I think this might lead to wrong behavior in some cases, but I don't immediately have a solution. What about converting to Mpccm, then using pf.arr to create new unit registries or something? Hmm.

content.raw: FWIW, now that PlotCollection is fully gone we are free to refactor this to be more nicely compatible with PlotWindow.  It would take some effort due to the number of callbacks but it might be worth it in the end to reduce future maintenance burden.
content.html: FWIW, now that PlotCollection is fully gone we are free to refactor this to be more nicely compatible with PlotWindow. It would take some effort due to the number of callbacks but it might be worth it in the end to reduce future maintenance burden.

content.raw:
I wrote some docs on this here: 

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/analyzing/units/comoving_units_and_code_units.html

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/analyzing/units/comparing_units_from_different_datasets.html

I agree that what you're doing is sensible, so long as you convert to a physical unit like Mpc you should be fine comparing units from different datasets.
content.html:
I wrote some docs on this here:

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/analyzing/units/comoving_units_and_code_units.html

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/analyzing/units/comparing_units_from_different_datasets.html

I agree that what you're doing is sensible, so long as you convert to a physical unit like Mpc you should be fine comparing units from different datasets.

content.raw: Are there future plans to add back in any of the functionality that's being removed? The old routines included options to annotate the circles with either the number of particles in the halo, the halo mass, or the halo id. The new callback also doesn't replace the functionality of annotate_hop_particles. It may be that no one actually used any of this functionality, but it's probably worth discussing if there aren't any plans to re-implement it.
content.html: Are there future plans to add back in any of the functionality that's being removed? The old routines included options to annotate the circles with either the number of particles in the halo, the halo mass, or the halo id. The new callback also doesn't replace the functionality of annotate_hop_particles. It may be that no one actually used any of this functionality, but it's probably worth discussing if there aren't any plans to re-implement it.

While it's true that this doesn't replicate all the old functionality, I think it would be relatively straightforward to do so.

The main issue with the old callbacks is that the old HOP halo finder no longer works with the current state of yt and I believe we're moving in the direction of simply replacing it with Rockstar in the upcoming release. To restore the HOP halo finder and associated plot callbacks someone would need to go through and update it to function correctly with the current state of yt.

Hilary Egan what do you think about implementing some of the functionality provided by the HOP particle callback and HOP circle callbacks in the new halo callback? Don't take that as a request to necessarily drop everything and do it, but just as a check to see if you'd be interested. Matt Turk Britton Smith might also know more about the state of halo finders in yt and the plans for HOP and PHOP.

content.raw:
The broader halo finding questions might be a better fit to the mailing
list than the PR, but the removed functionality is probably fair game here.
 :)
content.html: The broader halo finding questions might be a better fit to the mailing list than the PR, but the removed functionality is probably fair game here. :)

content.raw:
Mk, I can put that additional annotation functionality back in, although I won't promise it will be immediately. I thought I had gotten everything they did, so my mistake on not reading closely enough.
As far as the old halo finders go both FOF and HOP have been made compatible with the new halo catalog functionality, but I wouldn't say they're supported on their own as a lot of the functionality that went along with them is duplicated and is much more clear when using the halo catalogs.
content.html: Mk, I can put that additional annotation functionality back in, although I won't promise it will be immediately. I thought I had gotten everything they did, so my mistake on not reading closely enough. As far as the old halo finders go both FOF and HOP have been made compatible with the new halo catalog functionality, but I wouldn't say they're supported on their own as a lot of the functionality that went along with them is duplicated and is much more clear when using the halo catalogs.

description:
This can be used to annotate a plot with halos found using a halo catalog. It is designed to be a replacement for the outdated annotate_hop_particles and annotate_hop_circles. An example script using this feature can be found here: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4557/.

The circle size is scaled to the virial radius of the halo. There are optional arguments of color, transparency, and width. Width sets the size of the slab to plot halos inside of, used mainly for slice plots.
